Comment: The main interest I see in this game is the battle for key squares. Black's play is positionally sound, yet not particularly brilliant; White hoped to draw the endgame and was very close to the target...

Remembering the lesson of the game against piratiizi, and allowing eventually a3 without getting forked by the knight.

Forgetting the lesson against piratizii. This is not necessary. "The threat is stronger than its execution" - wrote Nimzowitch: if the idea is to take d5 uncovering the queen, it will work if the bishop is in c2, since there is check in h7.

There the chance goes! The White must confine the king to the side to have chances of draw:

49. Qf6 Qd4 50. Kg2 Kh5 51. f3 Qb2+ 52. Kh3 Qd4 53. Kg2 and now if the Black does not draw, loses after 54. g4+
